ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: I probably spent around 4 hours a week for this course.
For 2-page summaries, about 7 hours or more per week to go through research and write something thorough. Each exam typically took about a combined 12 or more hours per week.
2 hours per week
8-12 hours per week
2-3 hours/week (not including midterm and finals week)
4-8 hrs per week

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I think that the course material is incredibly relevant for the field of Public Health. I believe that one of the greatest weaknesses is it needs a bit more structure within each system. For example, if that day the system covered is the GI, a few minutes should be spend rudimentary explaining the system itself, then specific physiological functions of the GI and how they bridge with public health concern, and finally a discussion or student participation in course.I wish we had more group-solving problems and projects rather than discussions. We could even have more student led presentations. Instead of leaving them all at the end, we could assign one every other lecture or once a month.Even though the course is somewhat structured this way, I feel like it lacked defined specific goals, and rather than gaining knowledge on specific issues of relevance, I feel I obtained minimal understanding of physiological phenomenon and Public Health relevance.The write-ups are an excellent idea, but they should be narrowed down to allow for better discussions among students. The topics were so diverse that it was hard to comment on each. Maybe specific subtopics can be assigned within the topic.I also think that a midterm would be a good idea to force students to review material covered in class.

I really enjoyed this course, especially the fact that we combined physiological concepts with public health. If there was a weakness, I felt like we covered a lot of material in less depth. Maybe it would have been a better idea to go into fewer concepts more in depth.

The course helped orient me about the body's specific systems and how it functions altogether via its vast dependency and similarities to one another. I learned a lot and the 2-page summaries were excellent supplemental devices to enhance and reinforce this learning. The freedom to investigate a topic relative to the specific body system being studied allowed me to satiate my intellectual curiosity and learn the topic better as opposed to discrete and limited topic choices. Dr. Yeckel is a highly effective presenter on the topics. The ability to interact with classmates and intellectually enhance our various perspectives in the material helped to bring about new ideas and make the learning atmosphere much more open/friendly. This is also demonstrated by the willingness to share our knowledge with the public via wikipedia, which helps to promote scientific transparency--a valiant and necessary aspect to aid public health and research!To improve the course, I would recommend that the syllabus entail that a student will be assessed by 3 exams. Slightly clearer communication during class about assignments and future expectations would help too. The possibility of approaching the 2-page summaries differently (e.g. powerpoint presentation, debate?) week-by-week to provide different perspectives and approaches would help break the monotony a bit and allow one to understand the clear discrepancies between the physiological, financial, and public health components of a subject. Someone who has had little physiology or biology will have difficulty in grasping concepts, but with determination and extra help, one can overcome this.
The course is comprehensive, yet tailored to students' specific interests, especially in the public health arena
Excellent course! Highly interesting, and learned a lot about physiological basis for chronic disease, microbial disease, etc.

This class was very interesting in that incorporated both basic science and public health applications. I really enjoyed the scope of every lecture. The primary strength of this class is the range of perspectives (from microscopic to epidemiological) in which health was taught.I would have liked to have learned a bit more about the nervous system and public health. It might have also been interesting to have had more direction for our weekly assignments (such as current events, controversies, etc.). I agree with Professor Yeckel's original criteria of having the course for second-year MPH students in the future to allow for more in-depth discussion of epidemiological considerations of the concepts discussed.
very interactive class.

With this class I was hoping for a more broad overview of physiology and how the body works. The class focuses on small in-depth aspects of physiology rather than broad concepts. The weekly writings, while time-consuming, were helpful in learning about things I was interested in regarding physiology and public health. There were Wiki assignments which seemed like an after-thought and took focus away from the class itself.
This was an excellent course for students with different levels of ohysiology background.

Learning about how physiology and public health relate is a very interesting topic. Dr. Yeckel is an excellent and very passionate instructor and she tailors the lectures and discussion sessions according to the students' interests. It seems like second year students would benefit more from this class than first year students as knowledge on epidemiology is important for this class. The midterm and final exam pose thought-provoking questions that are applicable to the current public health issues in the real world. And the weekly write-ups were a great opportunity to explore an area of interest. We also had wiki projects. The concept was an interesting one, however, I did not get much out of these assignments.
Great topic for public health.
Energetic professor but the material is poorly organized.Did not like the forced weekly discussion.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Professor Yeckel is incredibly encouraging. She is a wonderful physiologist and is incredibly knowledgeable in the field. She is incredibly approachable and willing to meet each of her students needs. I am really humbled by her passion for her students, and her time for us. Her passion for the body and population health is so evident in her lectures. It was great to get to know her.Perhaps the only recommendation would be to define a bit more specific goals for each lecture so the students can better understand and focus on key important aspects of the system and relevance in public health.
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Dr. Yeckel was awesome! I loved her enthusiasm. She was extremely responsive and really cared about our learning.

Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Dr. Yeckel is a wonderful presenter on the topics being studied and is very fair, when it comes to updating students who miss a class. Her handouts were extraordinarily helpful in clarifying topics that were highly complex like the cardiovascular system. Her grading is helpful and she can definitely answer any question any student had about something.

Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Dr. Yeckel is one of the most knowledgeable and experienced professors at Yale University. In addition, she is equally kind and generous with her time and efforts. Her dedication to her students is second to none.
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Dr. Yeckel is a wonderful instructor - very helpful and really engages students!!

Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Professor Yeckel was among the best professors I have had during my time at Yale. She was not only knowledgeable, but also clearly dedicated to the course. I appreciated her sharing additional resources and articles of interest at our request or in response to our writings. She was always approacheable and consistently provided great feedback on our assignments.
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Dr. Yeckel is very passionate about the material, which excites the students
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Cathy is engaging and enthusiastic.
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Dr. Yeckel encouraged each student to explore his/her own interest in this course. The variety of students paired very well with the lectures.
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  See above
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  She was very understanding of students' different backgrounds and offered very good advice.
Instructor: Catherine Yeckel  Very nice and responsible professor. But a lot of works especially towards the end of the semester, and she has high personal expectation for her students.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Tiffanie is a very knowledgeable person. I appreciate and really enjoyed her lectures. I don't think she made herself approachable to the students. Also at many times, her responses to our questions during her lectures or outside of the class sounded incredibly demeaning to me personally and other students.
Tiffanie was a great TA. She was always extremely prepared. She gave a couple lectures, which were very informative and helpful. She was also really responsive.

The TA, Tiffanie Jones, definitely was very knowledgeable about the topics. Her presentations were very thorough and performed excellently. Would have liked if she was a little more involved in the class via standard communications and more helpful suggestions, though.
Tiffanie Jones was a helpful and responsible teaching assistant.
Tiffanie Jones - excellent TA, gave wonderful presentations and really helped students understand material!!

Tiffany did a great job as a TA. She gave us very interesting lectures, although at times I felt they were packed with so much information that they were difficult to follow when covered too quickly. She was also always accessible and gave good feedback.
Good TA
Not really sure having a TA really changed the class at all.
Tiffanie Jones was a great TA for the physiology course. She was always responsive to emails& did a couple excellent lectures during the course.
Great ta. Talks super fast though.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend it for your second year. I think it if it had better defined goals it would drastically improve.
This course was really fun. I learned a lot of interesting things about the body and how they pertain to current issues in public health.

I would recommend this course for students interested in understanding the human body and its various functions to form a single organism. Everything is cutting edge in the science and certainly, Dr. Yeckel has knowledge of or is participating in research investigating a new discovery in the subject matter!Having a TA is helpful to supplement discussions and provide additional nuances on the science behind topics.Again, students without any biological or physiological knowledge prior to taking the class will definitely have difficulty in accomplishing assignments or at least require more time catered to understanding it.

The course is relevant for students interested in physiology, especially those interested in working in the public health field. The instructor is open-minded and flexible with her approach to the material. Overall, an exemplary public health course.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND this course! Readings/materials before lecture were helpful, and weekly paper assignments followed by group discussion made the class very interactive. Lecture organized very well..overall very applicable. Encouraged students to think beyond physiology to public health interventions, and how we can use our knowledge in real-world settings.

This course covers both basic science (physiology) and more global public health approaches to human health. I would recommend it to both classmates who do and do not have a biology background for a unique perspective to public health.
none
This is not exactly a typical physiology course so if you are looking to get a good grasp of physiology I would not recommend it. It is an interesting class though with the write-ups every week.
See above
Good for people with a little biological background.
Good course with heavy biology as the name suggested. Much work compared to other classes, can be stressful at times.
